WOMAN.</br>What news — what news — O Traveller!</br>What tidings of the fight?</br>I have been watchful all day long—</br>I watch'd all yester'night.</br>No Traveller has past this way—</br>No tidings reach'd mine ear;</br>And I have watch'd, and watch'd for news,</br>'Till I am sick with fear.

TRAVELLER.</br>'Tis done — the victory is gain'd;</br>And I past thro' Bosworth town,</br>And in a cart his carcase saw</br>Who lately wore a Crown.</br>I heard the Conqu'ror's army make</br>With shouts the welkin ring:</br>I heard the clamours that proclaim'd</br>Young Richmond England's King.
WOMAN.</br>Oh!  tell me, tell me, Traveller,</br>If you a Youth have seen—</br>A comely Youth in Richmond's host,</br>Array'd in Kendal green?
TRAVELLER.</br>Many a gallant Warrior there,</br>And comely, I have seen;</br>There's many a Youth in Richmond's host</br>Array'd in Kendal-green.
WOMAN.</br>His eye is black — so black and bright!</br>His raven locks are long,</br>And he is one you could not chuse</br>But notice 'mid the throng.

TRAVELLER.</br>Beneath a helm I could not see</br>His raven locks so long;</br>And sooth to say I did not stay</br>To gaze amid the throng;</br>I just beheld young Richmond pass,</br>And then I hasten'd on.

WOMAN.</br>Dead!  dead!  oh God!  he must be dead!</br>Or sure this could not be!</br>He would have ask'd you where you went,</br>That he might send to me:</br>He would have let no Traveller</br>Now pass unquestion'd by;</br>For well he knows how I should watch,</br>And wait in agony.

TRAVELLER.</br>Cheer up!  cheer up!  and take good hope,</br>I did but hurry by;</br>And like it is that he might not</br>A single Trav'ller spy.</br>Cheer up!  cheer up!  and hope the best,</br>And spare these hasty tears;</br>A little while, and he may come,</br>And you forget your fears.
WOMAN.</br>Oh!  tell me, Trav'ller, did you pass</br>Across the bloody plain—</br>And did you see no comely Youth</br>Like him among the slain?
TRAVELLER.</br>Many a comely Youth I saw</br>Upon that bloody plain;</br>Many a groaning wretch I heard</br>Half dead amid the slain:</br>Christ grant that may never see</br>So sad a sight again!
WOMAN.</br>You saw him — yet you will not tell:</br>You saw him — he is dead!</br>O!  tell me — tell me — any thing</br>Were better than this dread!
TRAVELLER.</br>I hasten'd o'er the hateful plain,</br>And saw the suff'rer there.</br>Take comfort — I will, as I go,</br>Remember you in pray'r.</br>
